title: 106_s382
content: The Act may be cited as the "Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missile launch control facility and launch facility known as "Delta 1" and "Delta 9" are of national significance as preserved examples of American history during the Cold War. These facilities symbolize the dedication and preparedness of Air Force missileers in remote locations. The Act aims to preserve and interpret these structures for future generations and highlight the historical role of the Minuteman II missile defense system. The Act aims to preserve, protect, and interpret the structures associated with the Minuteman II missile defense system for present and future generations. It also seeks to highlight the historical role of the system in America's strategic commitment to world peace during the Cold War, complementing programs offered by the South Dakota Air and Space Museum. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established to preserve structures related to the Minuteman II missile defense system and showcase its historical significance during the Cold War. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site in South Dakota is established as part of the National Park System, consisting of the Minuteman II ICBM launch control facilities. The site includes the Delta 1 and Delta 9 Launch Control Facilities, with a map available for public inspection. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to make adjustments to the site's boundary. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to make minor adjustments to the boundary of the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site. The site shall be administered in accordance with relevant laws and the Secretary shall consult with other agencies to ensure compliance with treaties. The Secretary may acquire land within the historic site through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency, with restrictions on acquiring contaminated land. Cooperative agreements with public and private entities can be made to carry out the Act. Coordination with the Secretary of Defense and Secretary of State is required to ensure compliance with treaties. The Secretary can acquire land within the historic site through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency, with restrictions on acquiring contaminated land. A general management plan must be prepared within 3 years, including evaluation of suitable locations for visitor facilities and administrative sites. Acquisition of South Dakota land is limited to donation or exchange. The Secretary will evaluate suitable locations for a visitor facility and administrative site within designated areas on the map. Once a location is determined, the historic site boundary will be modified to include the selected site. Coordination with Badlands National Park for administrative functions will also be considered in the planning process. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums necessary for this Act. Air Force funds transferred for historic site establishment, operation, and maintenance. Legacy Resource Management Program funds unaffected.
